reviews.review: 刚刚结束了单人模式，虽然我没有玩过一代，但这一作真的相当不错。我平常很少接触解谜类游戏，但《传送门2》确实吸引住我了。一开始进入破碎的世界的不安，到后面渐入佳境的惊险，被Wheatley背叛的惊讶，和GLaDOS合作的又害怕最后被反咬一口的紧张，以及最后回到地面上时的感动，都值得品味。最喜欢的一段莫过于最后站在电梯上，看着炮塔集体唱歌的剧情，直接戳入心底的感动。好像剧透太多了……配乐相当赞，很符合气氛，解谜也有很多乐趣，难度循序渐进的提升，完全不会出现一下子太难而一筹莫展的情况，真心推荐玩一玩。
It is really cool and good

I bought the Bundle. At first I didn't really like to play Portal 1. But then, I tried the Portal 2, which has more possibilities and puzzles. I just finished playing today. The Storyline is just GREAT. [spoiler] Wheatley, I miss you! [/spoiler]

In some ways better some ways not but still a must play.

Portal 2 takes the first game and tries to make it bigger and better and defiantly gets the first part right.  I'm not going to spoil anything here i'll just sum things up.

The game is longer and at times that can be a bad thing because some of the challenges start to ware a little thin, and you spend varous parts of the game looking off into the distance for a protal compatable surface.  Its bigger but a little unwieldy but its still tons of fun and manges to add some new physics to the mix.

The gameplay its self is pretty much the same.  there are some new physic elements that add to the mix and these are handled very well though when you add them to portal use things can get kind of overwhelming, fortuantly they gradually easy you in to how they work just like they did with portals, unfortuantly that means your going to have to go through gradual tutorial style puzzles mulitpule times in the game.  Not a deal breaker but it does make the game drag a little between the funny bits.

The humor is still dead on.  the writting is great.  and i can not stress enough how awsome cave johnson is.

thats really all i can say about it other than it has a co-op campagin now thats actually alot of fun too.  Well designed, not too hard and more funny bits.

So yeah if you liked the first one...you've already bought this one.  If you haven't go play the first one. you'll proabley like it and then you'll buy this one.

Portal 2, sin duda el mejor juego que he jugado. Te da una gran motivacion, pero a la vez una desmotivacion acabar el juego; ya que tienes ganas de mas y tiene un gran final. Un juego muy recomendado; comprenlo carajo!

Um dos melhores jogos que tive a oportunidade de aproveitar, portal 2 possui uma história interessante com tons de humor e sarcasmo por parte de seus personagens mecânicos, Glados e Wheatley, é interessante ter um domínio básico de inglês para não ficar tão pertido (a) tanto na história quanto nas dicas que são dadas a cada estágio. Um jogo com foco em puzzles, não é necessário jogar portal para entender o portal 2, mas também recomendo olhar um pouco da história do primeiro jogo para estar mais situado quanto ao universo do jogo de maneira geral.
O modo multiplayer é ótimo, trazendo puzzles com foco para duas pessoas, fazendo com que os jogadores tenham que interagir para obter sucesso em cada estágio.
Espero que tod@s tenham a mesma diversão que eu em Portal 2, também com os seus amigos.

No idea why I am reviewing this game, but here we go.

Portal.  Play it.  Play it now.  Easily one of my top three favorite games of all time, Portal is amazing in every way.  From creative dialog to the now-famous mechanics, there’s not much I can say about this game in a broad sense that has not already been said.  Both the single player and co-op modes are fully realized and are a ton of fun to play through, time and time again.  It’s one of those games you can play thirty times and still find humor or something new in it.

Now the thing I can really say stuff about - the achievements.  I’m a hardcore completionist, and my work on Portal was some of the most fun I have had, grinding at the same level over and over again.  To get all 51 achievements, you not only need to complete both the single player and co-op campaigns, but you also must discover more obscure things hidden within levels.  The non-story based ones range in difficulty from fairly simple (if you know what you’re doing) to brutally complicated (Still Alive and Smash TV - I’m looking at you here).  It took me 30 hours to complete all the achievements.  With this in mind, it’s clear to see that it’s a doable task, yet not the thing for everyone. (but let’s say that the joy I got upon getting that last achievement was pretty great.)

Seriously go play this game now, your life will never be the same.

Overall rating: 10/10

***This review is for the story mode of Portal 2 only***

This is overall a worthy successor to Portal. In terms of gameplay, at least. The puzzles are infinitely more fun and varied, and there is so much richness that comes with the section of the game devoted to backstory. 

Sadly, it all comes at the expense of altering the tone of the whole game. Your original antagonist, GLADoS, is back--but is nothing like the cold, humourless, emotionless AI who ran the facility in the first game. There are some possible fridge logic reasons for this, but nothing is stated in-game about her personality change. It's a jarring note and it almost destroys the first game's experience as a result. Almost.

The othe rmain character, a robot which helps you escape the crumbling facility and get to safety is called Wheately. Wheatley is funny in a bumbling way, completely at odds with the tone of what Portal was. In a roundabout way, his manner can be related to the plot, but it doesn't fit with what you are expecting. You find yourself impatiently waiting for him to finish his jabber, instead of enjoying him as part of the experience of the game. In another game, he would have been a star.

But Cave Johnson... ah, Cave Johnson. You rich, crazy, authoritarian, smooth-voiced genius, you. Did I mention the crazy? Although you never meet him, his voice dominates the midlle part of the game and is a much-needed return to the casual disregard for human life and the black humour that made the first game what it was.

"If you don't have tumours, don't worry. If you sat on a folding chair in the lobby and weren't wearing lead underpants, we took care of that too."

If you didn't play Portal, you will love this game unreservedly. If you did play Portal, you will enjoy it. 

If you want to play both games, my recommendation is still that you play Portal first. I did and I think if I had done it the other way around, I would have been disappointed in the first game. Whereas I played them chronologically and it allows for greater appreciation of the first game, if at the expense of the second. And the first game is important, even though this review is about Portal 2. It's the blueprint that 2 is based on. It's the skeleton, where Portal 2 is the flesh. And the skeleton's job is to carry the weight. 

What do I mean by this? Well, despite the enjoyment you will gain from only playing Portal 2, it'll be a shallow enjoyment. Playing Portal and then Portal 2 allows you to wallow in a deeper enjoyment and, yes, to feel that disappointment. It's worth it.

So obviously, from the first game, you kill GLaDOS, and all of that happens. After you escape the building, you are somehow found by the labrotories and, of course, GLaDOS. You are put into a deep sleep, and like, three years later or something like that, you wake up in a dark dusty, dirty room, not like the one you went to sleep in. Then another character comes into the story. A core named Wheatley comes knocking on your door. You want to know who it is, so obviously, you open it. He comes in, talks for a bit, and then the room starts moving, smashing into walls, until you jump out. Then you are put into a whole lot of test chambers. I could beat most of them, some of them it took me a bit to figure them out. What I really didn't like was how Wheatley, my favorite character, turns into the bad guy. I've beaten the game, and my favorite chapter is 'The Part Where He Kills You', so sometimes, if I don't want to play from the beginning, I will play that chapter. So, my favorite part of that chapter is when I'm in his lair. I know what to do, how to do it, but I think it's cool when I shoot a portal to the moon, and everything gets sucked in. It really stands out to me when GLaDOS deletes Caroline, and her voice changes, I don't like how she gets rid of me. I like the ride up, the singing turrets and all that, I don't like how I'm in a feild with no city around me, or no building around me. If she was going to get rid of me, why not leave me close to a city? I really think they should make a free Portal three game of me getting back into the building, hanging out with GLados, Wheatley coming back and apologizing and bemcoming friends with us again, and let me be able to go out to the city, live in a house, and be able to visit GLaDOS and Wheatley. I really want to see what happens after that. I don't like how GLaDOS got rid of me, and how there's no city near me, and how I don't know what happens after that. I really want Valve to make another Portal.

What do you think?

Portal 2 is a great game. I recommend you buy when it goes on sale (it's not exactly worth the normal price). One flaw that it has is that the single player mode is quite short (I only got about 12 hours out of it). Luckily there is a fun multiplayer mode for you to enjoy so that kind of makes up for it. In conclusion, if you like puzzle games and you want a fun adventure in both single player and multiplayer pick up this game on sale (I got mine for 3.99, I regret nothing).

I would rate Portal 2 8.9/10. The graphics, controls, plot, and audio are fantastic. But the time it takes you to beat the single player mode is so short that I couldn't give it a 9. Basically if they upped the single player mode by making the game about 4 times longer (with new and innoveative things as the game progresses) I would give it a 10/10.

This is a solidly built game with not a single bug that I noticed and is perhaps one of the more simultaneously stressful and exhilarating games I have recently played (so stressful that like the first Portal game, I do not see myself ever wanting to play this game again). I think it is also the most topsy-turvy, vertiginous game I have ever played (even more so than Forsaken in some ways). The plot is simple (with basically the same goal as the first Portal game, to escape the facility). The graphics are wonderful (and interestingly styled, in an ultra-utilitarian and extremely clean and often stark manner), the gameplay is intellectually challenging (and often mind-bending), but I found the characters to be largely irritating distractions with primarily unfunny jokes. Generally the game feels like whoever wrote the dialogue for it may have thought that they were far more funny than they actually were. The game feels full of itself oftentimes. Most jokes fell flat (for me) though the ones that were funny really were excellent in an absurdist sort of way. The funniest thing in the game, the corrupted fact core, I have posted in the comments below. Overall this game is a very oddly balanced combination of intellectual challenge, stress, fun and irritation. Playing it I found to be a sort of intellectually masochistic experience...probably a fun enough game to play through once...but I would not want to repeat the experience.

Pros: Great, interestingly styled, clean graphics, no bugs at all, great controls, great sound, interesting (though occasionally annoying) music, lots of intellectual, mind-bending challenge throughout, intense (but up to and past the point of being stressful), If you are good ad 3-dimensional visual-spacial reasoning this game will make you feel very intelligent as you run through the game solving puzzle after puzzle in 10 minutes or less, good ending which makes me want to go outside and not be in by my computer for a while. A great final-boss level with an excellent, surprising, truly funny ending, the designers left the best parts of this game to the end.

Cons: Linear gameplay with puzzles which mostly have only one essential answer, only 1 ending, graphics can seem a bit stark at times (though this is part of the game's inherent uniqueness, irritating, largely unfunny characters, If you're good at the game the game can be quite short (but I got the game for only 5 dollars),
